To The Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf. S.S. BANKURA - MISBEHAVIOUR OP IRANIAN PASSENGERS. When we intercepted the s.s. BANKURA for mails and provisions off the Quoins on her way to Bunder Abbas from Muscat on 24th September, 1936, the Master (Captain John W. Milne) came on board and reported to me in the following sense. 2. While at Charbar on 2Pnd September on his present run the following were among the Iranian passengers who embarked there for Bunder Abbas Mahomed Dorrani Gurbani, Corporal, Persian Road Police. Mohamed Reza, Private ,, ,, ,, Mohamed All , Private, ,, ,, ,, who had in their custody, two prisoners accused of theft. 3. The Corporal stated he was going to take the prisoners to Teheran. 4. These police were all armed with rifles, and it was ascertained that these were loaded. 6. In accordance with the British India Steam Navigation Company’s orders the Chief Officer requested the Corporal to hand over his firearms for custody while on board, and told him they would be restored before the party landed at Bunder Abbas. The Corporal refused to do this. 6. The Chief Officer then brought the Corporal before the Master, who personally ordered him to hand over the rifles for custody. The Corporal again refused, saying that he would only surrender his arms if ordered to do so by one of hie own officers. 7. The ship had already left Charbar for Muscat. At Muscat the British Consul was in recess, and there was no Iranian Consul, but the B.I. Agent there again explained to these pdicemen that they should give up their rifles in accordance with the Company’s regulations. This had no effect.8. So at the time when the Master reoorted to me the Iranian Police in hie ship were still walking about with loaded rifles in defiance of his orders. 9. The Master stated he did not want to risk a brawl by- ordering his own officers and men to disarm these policemen. As the Master said he anticipated no trouble whatever from the policemen if left to themselves, I decided not to send over an armed party to disarm them, and the Master preferred that no action of this kind should be taken. 10. The Master’s object in making the report is to have the Iranian authorities’ attention drawn to this flagrant act on the part of their officials in order that it may not be repeated. 11. The Master also informed me that he considers it most humiliating that he should be defied like this, especially as the Iranian Authorities are continually harassing the B.I. Mail Steamers with petty regulations and fining the Masters for disregard of Regulations which have never been published. 12. I told the Master that I would report the matter through Service channels together with his request that some action may be taken with the Iranian Government to prevent a repetition. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in rough chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 23; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: Correspondence regarding British India Steamship Navigation Company regulations that armed Persian [Iranian] Officers should give up their weapons when transporting prisoners on vessels flying the British flag.The correspondence dated 1930 concerns the arrest of Sirdar Din Mohamed of Dashtyari [Dashtīārī], and his transport from Charbar [Chabahar] to Bushire [Bandar Būshehr], escorted by armed officers. It includes details of attempts by the Persian Government to disarm the tribes in Dashtyari, and British concerns that Baluchi tribes would destroy local telegraph lines in retaliation. The file contains communications received from the Board of Trade, the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, the Senior Naval Officer Commanding in the Persian Gulf, and the Director of the Persian Gulf Section of the Indo-European Telegraph Department.The correspondence dated 1936 concerns an incident where Persian Road Police escorting prisoners from Charbar to Bunder Abas [Bandar Abbas] refused repeated instructions that they give up their weapons and ammunition to the ship's crew. The Commanding Officer of the HMS Bidefordsubmits a formal complaint to the Persian authorities.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is found at the end of the correspondence (folio 2).
